In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: to buys raw materials for her work

loans.name: Sani Bahini

texts.en:
Sani Bahini T., 46, is married and has two children, 24 and 22 years old. In 1990, she established her farming business, and by working six days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and repaid two loans from Patan BPW, having used her most recent one to purchase additional farming materials. In the future, Sani Bahini plans to supply vegetable produce to local store. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

This loan is administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: Farming materials

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Akouvi W. est une femme de 49 ans très dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois. étant la seule à faire ce commerce dans son quartier elle a une grande clientèle et réalise par conséquent de bonnes recettes. elle s'approvisionne à l'intérieur du pays, la demande actuelle de sa clientèle est élevée, elle sollicite donc de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat d'une vingtaine de sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise. elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants
texts.en:
Akouvi W. is a very energetic 49 year old woman. Her line of business is selling charcoal. As she is the only person operating this type of business in her neighborhood, she has a large clientele and consequently makes a good income. She gets her supplies in the interior of the country and at present customer demand is high. She is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES to buy around twenty bags of charcoal and to provide for the transportation of the merchandise. She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Shanti

texts.en: This is 49 year-old Shanti C.. She is married and has 3 children aged 28, 25, and 20. In 1998, she established her small store business. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to purchase additional inventory for her small store. In the future, Shanti plans to continue adding inventory and expanding her business. She thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: purchasing inventory for store

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 37 years old and has three children, aged 2, 10, and 12 years. Two of her children are in school, while the other is not yet of school age.

Francoise and her husband are both welders. She has been in the business for 16 years. She is a person of integrity and she makes good equipment. For these reasons, people like the products she sells.

She is asking for a loan in order to buy more raw materials so she can increase production and make more profits.

loans.use: To buy raw materials in order to increase welding production.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 34 years old. She is married with one child who is four years old. Her child is in primary school and her husband is a businessman.

Alice has a shop in which she sells household items such as soap, salt, and matches. Her clients are mostly people in her neighborhood. She says that she has a good relationship with them.

She is requesting a loan in order to buy more items to fill her store. This will allow her clients to always find what they need in her store.

loans.use: To purchase household items to sell in her store

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa is married with six children. All of her children attend school. She does not care for additional family members. Kasifa resides in and owns a house which has electricity, but no piped water. Her greatest expenses are school fees, food and medication.

She works in a semi-urban area selling charcoal. She buys bags of charcoal from Mubende, one of the districts which makes up central Uganda. Kasifa uses public transportion to and from Mubende so she can buy the charcoal. She goes there once a week.

Kasifa wants to use this loan of 1,000,000 UGX to buy more bags of charcoal. She has been in the business for ten years and with MCDT for twelve years. Besides this charcoal business she also owns rental rooms to earn additional income.

Kasifa sells charcoal to all types of people, both retail and wholesale. She sells her bags of charcoal from Nakawa market. Her customers are people from the area. She works six days a week. Her major business challenge is transportation.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Latékoé

texts.fr: Monsieur L. est un homme marié et père de 3 enfants. il vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de hedzranawoé, il est électricien d'automobile, il a ouvert à ce effet son garage qu'il a appelé "ALLS CONCEPT". il a des commandes de ses clients qu'il n'a pas encore exécuté parce que ne disposant pas de matériaux appropriés. il souhaite acheter du matériel approprié raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers matériaux devant lui permettre d'exécuter ses commandes.
texts.en:
Mr. L. is married and the father of three children. He lives with his family in the Hedzranawoé district. He is a automotive electrician. He has his own auto shop named “Alls Concept.” He has some repair jobs pending because he lacks the necessary materials. He would like to purchase some necessary materials, which is why he is seeking a loan from WAGES to purchases various supplies needed to carry out his work.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing work supplies

loans.name: Tamara's Group

texts.en:
Tamara S. is the leader of the group. She is 44 years old and divorced. She has raised five sons and a daughter. Three sons work in her sewing workshop and the other children study at school.

Ten years ago with an initial investment of 50,000 soms, Tamara opened a sewing workshop. She works there with her sons. By taking orders and selling different clothes, Tamara makes 18,000 soms per month.

She applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase fabric and materials for sewing the clothes. In the future, Tamara plans to purchase more sewing machines to expand her business and buy a flat for each son.

Gulmira T., 43 years old, is married. She has a son who is six years old and a student. In order to make money, Gulmira’s husband works in construction. Five years ago, Gulmira borrowed 20,000 soms from her sister and started to sell fruits and vegetables at the market. Today, by selling fruits and vegetables, she makes 17,000 soms per month. With money received from this loan, Gulmira wants to purchase various fruits and vegetables in order to resell them. In the future, she wants to build a store, and adopt a girl from an orphanage.

Aaly A., 46 years old, is married. He has two daughters and a son. His older daughter works as baker in Bishkek, his son is a waiter in Russia, and his second daughter studies in school. Seventeen years ago with an initial investment of 30,000 soms, Aaly started selling fruits and vegetables. He makes 18,200 soms per month. With the money received from this loan, he wants to purchase fruits in order to resell them at a higher price. In the future, he wants to contribute some money to his daughter’s wedding and to purchase a flat for his son.

Taalaikul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 33 years old and married. She has two sons and a daughter. In order to make money, her husband works as driver and Taalaikul sells convenience goods in a kiosk. She has been doing this for eight years. Taalaikul started with an initial investment of 10,000 soms and now she makes 11,000 soms per month. With money received from this loan, she wants to purchase various goods to resell in her kiosk. In the future, she wants to build a big store and purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and materials

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 43 years old and married to a business-woman. They have four children who are between 10 and 14 years old.

Emmanuel owns goats, and with a loan he wishes to buy more goats to sell. He says he is known for good customer service and rears high quality goats. Both of these qualities contribute to his large clientele.

He wishes to make enough profit in order to buy goats to sell in the neighboring markets.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en: Seraphine is 43 years old, married and has four children who are between the ages 2 and 11. Her husband is a farmer, and she makes a living by selling different types of flour. She is applying for this loan in order to buy more flour to sell to her customers. Eventually, she hopes to buy other items to sell in her shop, and also open up a wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy flour to sell to her customers

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is 61 years old, separated from her husband and has one child who is 21 and in school. She makes a living selling various types of items, such as peanuts and cooking oil, and is held in high regard by her customers because these items are very high quality. Marie has applied for this loan to buy a greater range of goods to sell to her customers. She believes her clients will appreciate having more choice, and this will take her closer to her dream of opening a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en: Epiphanie is married and has three children who are ages four, seven and 10 years. Her husband makes a living by providing transportation services on a motorcycle, and shares her pride in having two children in school. Epiphanie contributes to the family's income by selling charcoal, a business she has been in for more than a decade. She is applying for this loan in order to increase her income by buying more charcoal to sell to her customers. She believes that her customers will buy these additional supplies because they know that her charcoal is of good quality and is sold at a reasonable price. Her dream is to open a wholesale business, and she believes she will be able to do this in the future.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell to her customers

loans.name: Latifa Lawani

texts.fr: L. lawani latifa est une couturière, elle dispose de son propre salon de coiffure et fait en même le commerce de divers produits cosmétiques.L. a obtenu déjà de WAGES un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite un autre crédit  pour approvisionner son stock de produits cosmétiques avec des mèches, perruques, pommades et autres produits cosmétiques. elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant. avec le revenu de son commerce elle contribue aux charges du ménage.
texts.en:
Lawani Latifa L. is a stylist. She keeps her own hair salon and, in addition, she also sells various cosmetic products. Ms. L. already obtained a loan from WAGES in the past and duly repaid it. She is now seeking another loan to replenish her stock of cosmetic products, as well as hair extensions, wigs, hair gel and other cosmetic products. She is married and the mother of one child. The revenue from her business allows her to contribute to the family budget.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing hair extensions, gels and various cosmetic products

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 40 years old and married with three children, ages 1, 13 and 16 years old. Jeanne has a photocopy machine and she uses this machine to provide photocopy services to her customers. The hours of her business are from 7 am until late in the evening hours.

Jeanne needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s. a.  to allow her to expand her business by purchasing one more photocopy machine. She plans to look for a market in a school where she can place this photocopy machine. If she is successful in purchasing this photocopy machine as well as getting this market place, she will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to continue taking care of her children and save for a better future.

loans.use: To buy one more photocopy machine

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
F. Gulbahor is a hard-working woman who is married and has four children. For the past three years, she has made a living selling office supplies and children's clothing. She started her business after her husband lost his job at a construction company and bills started to pile up. She likes her work, has developed a stable business, and is applying for a loan for $3,000 to buy new items to sell. Success is important to her family's well-being, which is why she hopes that Kiva lenders will be able to support her. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy office supplies and clothing to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Manuchehr

texts.ru: Усмонов Манучехр проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 25 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Живет вместе с матерью. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Манучехр не имеет высшего образования. Вместе с другом арендует помещение, где открыл дилерский центр. Он в основном продает сим карты, пополняет балансы, делает ксерокопию документов. В этой области уже 2 года. Кредит берет для закупа новых сим карт. Он хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить больше прибыли.
texts.en:
Manuchehr U. lives in Vahdat. He is 25 years old, married, and has one child. He lives with his mother. His wife is a housewife. Manuchehr does not have a higher education. He and his friend rent a space where he has opened a kiosk. He basically sells SIM cards, adds minutes to phone balances, and makes copies of documents. He has been doing this for two years. He is taking out a loan to buy new SIM cards. He wants to expand his business and earn a greater profit.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying new SIM cards

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, cooking oil, sugar, flour and pepper to sell to her customers

loans.name: Esinam Mireille

texts.fr: A. est une femme mariée et mère d'un enfant, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail d'oeufs. son stock actuel de marchandises ne permet pas de satisfaire toute sa clientèle raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 150 plateaux d'oeufs. ainsi avec ce nouveau stock elle pourra satisfaire ses clients et augmenter ses recettes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mireille A. is a married mother of one, who sells eggs to earn income. Her current stock is not enough to supply all her clients, and this is why she is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy 150 crates of eggs. With this additional stock, she will be able to supply her clients' needs and increase her revenues.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy eggs

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
Farida K. is the leader of the group. Forty-seven-years-old and married, she has three sons, the first of whom works in Russia, while the others study at school. In order to earn a living, Farida works as a teacher, while her husband is a painter. This year they have started to breed cattle, and with money received from the loan Farida wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In the future she plans to save some money to contribute to her son’s wedding.

Aishahan T. is 19 years old. A year ago with the initial investment of 200 soms she started to put credit on mobile balance (for each payment she gets 5 soms). In this way she makes 1000 soms per month. Now she wants to start sewing national cloth and dressmaking supplies. And she applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials. Navat S., 40, is married. She has a son and two daughters, both students. In order to make money Navat works as a nurse and her husband works in Russia. Navat also breeds cattle; she has been doing it for fifteen years. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In the future Navat wants to repair the house and save money to be able to pay for her children’s education at university. Asal S. is the treasurer of the group, 37. Sewing national cloth and dressmaking supplies Asal makes money to cover her personal expenditures. She has been sewing for 20 years and her monthly income is 7000 soms. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing. In the future she plans to open a sewing workshop. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf for breeding

loans.name: Javohir

texts.en:
F. Javohir is 56 years old. She is married and the mother of three adorable children. Javohir has a grocery store which she attends to herself, in addition to caring for her family and her home.

She began her small business 3 years ago with financial support from her husband, who is mechanic. The reason for starting the business was to increase her family’s income. The business has been gradually growing ever since.

In order to grow her business further, she requests a loan of $1,000 USD. Javohir is planning to spend the loan on more goods to sell, thus increasing the range of the goods she sells. She thanks everybody who decided to support her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell

loans.name: Koami

texts.fr: ce monsieur est un père de famille, il a 2 enfants; l'activité qu'il exerce pour subvenir aux charges de sa famille est la couture, il confectionne aussi des habits qu'il vend à ses clients. il veut acheter du matériel nécessaire à son activité de couture raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de doublures, tissus et d'une nouvelle machine à coudre
texts.en:
Mr. Koami B. is a head of household with two children. He operates a tailoring business to provide for the needs of his family. He also makes clothing that he sells to his clients. He wants to buy some material necessary for his tailoring business. He is requesting a loan from WAGES for the purchase of fabric, lining and a new sewing machine.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, lining and a sewing machine

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is married with four children. All of her children attend school. She also takes care of three orphans. She resides in and rents a house which has no electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, food, and school fees.

She owns a stall where she sells second-hand clothes. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. In addition to this clothing business, she owns a poultry farm at her home.

Jalia has been in this business for the last seven years. She works at the Bwaise market and sells to all types of people, both retail and wholesale.

She works six days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her main business challenge is the seasonality and transportation of bales of clothes from Owino market to Bwaise market, where she works.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
N. Saida is 22 years old. She has run her own business for five years, despite her young age. At the local market, she sells clothing for children.

Saida is very successful in her business. The business is the main source of income for her family.

IMON has provided Saida with a loan in the past. She has built a positive credit history without any violations. Today, she requests $1,500 USD.

This courageous lady plans to use the loan to increase the range of goods she sells and to improve the living of her family. Saida thanks everyone for trusting and supporting her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new goods sell

loans.name: Viloyatmo

texts.en:
Viloyatmo, divorced with no children and living with her parents, has a business selling clothing in the small market of Shahrituz. Her business is going well as demand has been very stable over the last eight years. An entrepreneur of high integrity, Viloyatmo is very hardworking and energetic. Even when her competitors have similar products or lower prices, clients naturally gravitate to her because she makes them feel valued, respected and heard.

Viloyatmo is now requesting a loan of 6500 Somoni to purchase seasonal clothing which will help her to continue stabilizing her business and income so that she can support herself and her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for the summer season.

loans.name: Usmonali

texts.ru: Рачабов Усмонали проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 56 лет. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Жена занимается домашним хозяйством. Сын в России на заработках. Сам Усмонали имеет средне - специальное образование, бухгалтер. По профессии проработал 20 лет. Сейчас он занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет небольшой земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 6 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений, чтобы посеет повторный урожай. Он хочет получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Usmonali R. lives in Vahdat. He is 56 years old, married, and has seven children. His wife is a housewife. His son is working in Russia. Usmonali has a vocational education as a bookkeeper. He worked in his trade for twenty years. Now he farms. At his house, he has a small plot where he grows vegetables. He has been doing this for more than six years. He is taking out a loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers in order to sow a second crop. He wants a good harvest to sell.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more palm oil and caustic to use in soap production

loans.name: Koffi Ofo

texts.fr: M. est un homme marié et père de 3 enfants. pour subvenir aux charges de sa famille, il s'est lancé en 2000 dans le commerce de détail de produits générique. il exerce ce commerce dans sa propre boutique. Son stock de marchandise est en baisse, il a déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu'il a bien remboursé; il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers produits génériques afin de pouvoir gonfler son stock. avec le revenu de son commerce il contribue aux charges du ménage.
texts.en:
Mr. M. is married and the father of threee children. In 2000, he went into the retailing of generic products. He runs his business in his own shop and his stock of merchandise is low. He has already obtained a loan from WAGES that he repaid in full. He is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy various generic products so he can build up his stock. He contributes to the expenses of the household with the income from his business.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of generic products

loans.name: Ikhbol

texts.en:
S. Ikhbol is a happy mother of 3 children. She is 44 years old and she is married.

Ikhbol has been running her own grocery business for the last 5 years. Her wish is to increase her business, offering various types of foodstuffs to her customers who pass through her market. She works with one aim in mind - to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children. Her children are the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts.

With this opportunity and with the immense love Ikhbol feels as a mother and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of $2,000 USD. She will use the loan to increase the range of goods she sells. You can be an important link in the growth of this business by supporting Ikhbol.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.en:
Sharofat’s principal occupation is the cultivation and production of vegetables. She is an excellent and admirable farmer who learned from her father the techniques and secrets of this beautiful activity. These skills have allowed her to develop multiple agricultural capabilities. They have enabled her to take care of her loving family, especially in these times of numerous financial problems.

Sharofat requests your help in the form of a loan, which will allow her to earn greater revenues this year so she can reach her goals. She is asking for a loan of $3,000 USD in order to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. She will also use part of the loan to buy cattle.

Sharofat expresses her gratitude to everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan on time.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en:
M. Gulchehra is 38 year old. She is married and has two children. She owns a specialized fabrics store at the central market in Shahrituz region. Gulchehra works in a sphere of trade where the demand is always very consistent and high because the national dresses in Tajikistan are very popular and very important items of the dowry of any girl. She is one of the leading fabrics vendors in the market where she works. She is very determined in all of her business endeavors, which has helped to sustain her venture for eight years. Gulchehra is a skilled entrepreneur. When she started this trade, she decided to implement basic concepts of integrity and hard work in her business to reach ultimate success. This laid a firm foundation for winning results and Gulchehra has obviously been a successful small entrepreneur. However, she doesn’t want to stop. She would like to continue seeing her venture grow. Today she is requesting a loan of 5200 Somoni to increase her assorted inventory. With your help, Gulchehra will be able to make his business succeed.

loans.use: Purchasing new fabrics for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: God’S Will Group

texts.en:
Mary D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "God’s Will". She is 45 years old, single and has eight children who range in age from 10 to 28 years old. Mary cares for four siblings. She was not privileged to attend school due to poverty. For 20 years, she has been selling fish (fresh and dried) in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

Mary plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 26,000 LRD group loan to buy more fish. She describes herself as a caring mother. Her dream is to expand her business, build a house and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more fish

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther N. M. is 24 years old, married and has two children: ages five years old and two months. Her business is located at Pipeline in Kisumu. She has been selling motor vehicle spare parts. She says that this business is profitable. The major challenge she has had is relocating several time and losing contact with her customers. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Esther is using her loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to buy motor spare parts to expand her business. She hopes to grow her business and become a wholesaler in future. She describes herself as self-motivated, result-oriented and persuasive.

loans.use: To buy motor vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Jumabek

texts.en: T. Jumabek is 44 years old, married and lives with wife and four children. He is a very hard worker, cultivating vegetables and fruits, an activity which he has practiced for nine years. He enjoys his work for the contact with nature and also because fruits and vegetables sell very well in the markets and are valued within his community. Currently, Jumabek needs a loan of $1000 US for his business. With this loan, he will buy seeds and fertilizers to improve the farming and get better production. loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Bahriniso

texts.ru: Кизилбоева Бахринисо проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 30 лет. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Муж находится на заработках в России. Сама Бахринисо имеет высшее образование, педагог. По профессии проработала 3 года. Так как зарплата была не большая, она стала заниматься бизнесом. Сейчас она имеет торговую точку на рынке, где продает ткани. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 7 лет. Кредит просит для увеличения товарооборота. Она намерена привести новый ассортимент сезонного товара.
texts.en:
Bahriniso K. lives in Yavan. She is 30 years old, married, and has one child. Her husband is working in Russia. Bahriniso has a higher education as a teacher. She worked in her field for three years. Since the salary was low, she started to work in business. Now she has a shop in the market where she sells fabric. She has been doing this for seven years. She is asking for a loan to increase her sales. She intends bring in a new assortment of seasonal goods.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Azamjon

texts.en: T. Azamjon is a 27-year-old farmer. He is married and has a 2-year-old son. His wife is a housewife and this makes him the sole breadwinner. He has been farming for the last eight years on his piece of land, growing tomato, cucumber, potato and melon. Azamjon would like to adopt new farming technology to boost his agricultural yield. He requests a 5500 somoni loan to be used for purchasing seeds and fertilizer for growing his crop. Azamjon is very responsible and is promising to repay the loan on time. loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Cathy

texts.en:
Cathy Nakiraga is 18 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Cathy has a business of selling fish, which she has had for less than one year.
  
To help expand her business, Cathy is requesting a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more fish for selling.  Cathy hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to go back for her studies.  In the future, Cathy hopes to see her business expand.

loans.use: more fish to sell

loans.name: Jori

texts.en:
T. Jori is dedicated to agricultural work, which is the only income he has to support his family.  In his family he has his wife and 7 children. He has been dedicated to this business for several years and over time he has gained experience in cultivating crops. Today Jori has come to IMON International with the proposition of obtaining a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer for planting. It is necessary to point out that in order to carry out the first planting you need to purchase the supplies and it is for this reason that Jori is confident that his loan request will be successfully granted and he will achieve his objective of having a good harvest to improve his economic situation.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children, 1 of whom is in school.  Halima has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for 2 years.  

To help expand her business, Halima is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell.  Halima hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to add more capital to her business.  In the future, Halima hopes to fly in an airplane.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for selling

loans.name: Farogat

texts.en:
H. Farogat is an enterprising, capable and very hard-working woman. She lives in Istaravshan, Tajikistan and sells kid’s clothing. She began her business after the death of her husband. Her work is allowing her three children go to school. It is very important to Farogat that her children finish school and become honest, hard-working individuals. She needs 6500 Somoni to buy merchandise in order to increase sales. Farogat wants to continue to support her children and only wishes to work in order to achieve this. Support her!

loans.use: Purchasing of the new clothing for selling.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
B. Ahmad is a lively entrepreneur with a small business selling shoes for teenagers. He is experienced entrepreneur having been self-employed for the past 10 years. Business has been good for Ahmad. There is always demand for clothing and as the economy has improved in Tajikistan more people have been able to afford new clothing. Ahmad is married and has two children. He is doing all his best to ensure his children with the best future. Ahmad has requested a loan of 6500 Somoni to increase his available working capital. Eventually, Ahmad hopes to have his own small store. This loan will help him purchase new inventory and continue to invest in his business.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new clothing for selling

loans.name: Women Of Destiny Group

texts.en:
Kemah Z., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women Of Destiny. She is 46 years old, married and has six children who range from 8 to 29 years old.  She was not able to attend school because she was living in poverty. Kemah cares for two siblings.

For 12 years, she has been selling rice, tobacco, palm oil and dried meat in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of rice, tobacco, palm oil and dried meat.  She describes herself as a service-oriented woman.  Her dream is to improve her business and  build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Evelyn is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, tobacco, palm oil and dried meat.

loans.name: Ismoil

texts.en:
Ismoil supports his family with a small business selling men’s and women’s clothing. He operates from a little space at the central market in Penjikent, Tajikistan, where he maintains a nice variety of clothing to choose from. Ismoil has been in business for 6 years. With good quality products and affordable prices, he has developed a solid customer base, and his business continues to grow. Ismoil has requested a loan to increase his working capital and allow him to purchase new inventory. This loan will help Ismoil maximize his profits and provide for his family.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new clothing for selling

loans.name: Najmiddin

texts.en:
Najmiddin has got a minivan and run a transportation service. His usual itinerary is the Isfara-Khujand-Isfara route. Have been in this business for 2 years he has gained significant experience. Initially he rented the car, but a little time, after making enough savings, he bought his own minivan with the support of his father. The business is now stable and generates the main income for Najmiddin’s family allowing them all to improve their living conditions. Currently his minivan needs some repairs, so he needs a loan of 7500 Somoni.

loans.use: Purchasing of the spare parts in order to repair his minivan.

loans.name: Havasmoh

texts.ru: Рахматуллоева Хавасмох проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 45 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Муж не работает. Сама Хавасмох занимается торговлей детской и подростковой одежды. Имеет богатый опыт в этой сфере. Товар привозит из города Душанбе. Ей помогает ее дочь. Этот бизнес приносит доход. Она одна обеспечивает семью. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Так как начинается школьный сезон, она намерена привезти школьную одежду.
texts.en:
Havasmoh R. lives in Yavan. She is 45 years old, married, and has four children. Her husband does not work. Havasmoh works selling clothes for children and teenagers. She has vast experience with this. She brings her goods from the city of Dushanbe. Her daughter helps her. This business brings in income. She alone provides for her family. She is taking out a loan to increase sales. She intends to bring in school clothes for the beginning of the school year.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Mahmudjon

texts.en:
K. Mahmudjon is a very hard and responsible entrepreneur. He and his family live in Isfara, Tajikistan. He is married and has two children. Mahmudjon together with his son (pictured) works in the central city market selling men’s clothing and shoes. His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. He has been working in the market for 5 years. Mahmudjon likes to work for himself. His business has been the main source of income for his whole family. Today Mahmudjon would like to ask for a loan of $1500 USD to purchase new inventory. We believe Mahmudjon‘s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business.

loans.use: Purchasing the new clothing for selling.

loans.name: Faizi

texts.en:
T. Faizi is married and has 3 children. With the faith that his children would go to college to get ahead, he started a business of processing and selling the dried apricot to be able to make enough money to pay for their schooling. This is why he started this business 5 years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business that allows him to expand his clientele day by day. Right now Faizi needs a loan of 4500 Somoni. He is going to spend the loan for purchasing apricots further to process it into dried apricots and to sell. Faizi will be able to feel proud that through much effort, his children went to college and are honorable people.

loans.use: To buy apricot for expanding his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, beans, oil, cheese, chicken, meat, sodas, juices, and other items

loans.name: Fullness Of Time Group

texts.en:
David S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Fullness Of Time. He is 53 years old, married and has six children whose ages range from 9 to 35. David was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulty.   

For five years, David has been selling charcoal in Thinkers Village outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 9,000 LRD portion of this 45,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of charcoal. He describes himself as an earnest man. His goal is to expand his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru: Узбекова Малика проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 38 лет. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Живет вместе с родителями. Не имеет высшее образование. После смерти мужа начила с малого бизнеса. Сейчас у нее собственный магазин, где она продает женскую одежду, ткани, нижнее белье. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Malika U. lives in Yavan. She is 38 years old, widowed, and has two children. She lives with her parents. She does not have a higher education. After her husband’s death, she started a small business. Now she has her own shop where she sells ladies’ wear, fabrics, and underwear. She has been doing this for five years. She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she sells.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing inventory

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James was born in 1977 and is single. He takes care of one dependent. James owns a small business selling various products such as cosmetics and supplies which are used for bread. This business is fruitful in his community. James has two years of experience in his business. The hours of his shop are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

James is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing more new products and offering another service like a public phone. Increasing his products will allow him to satisfy all the customers who are living near his residence. In so doing, James will be able to earn more profits.

loans.use: To expanding his business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala eastern region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children, who are not in school.  For less than a year, Betty has operated a business selling snacks, such as fish and chips. To help expand her business, Betty is requesting a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda, which she will use to buy oil for cooking.  Betty hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to add more capital to her business. In the future, Betty hopes to own a big shop.

Note to lenders:
BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more oil for cooking

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more mobile phones

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase sodas, juices, bottles of water, and baked goods

loans.name: Mother Blessing Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mother Blessing. He is 25 years old, single, has two children, 7 and 9 years old, and cares for one sibling. Emmanuel is a college student.

For 5 years, he has been selling charcoal on Newport Street, Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of charcoal. He describes himself as a determined man. His dream is to improve his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles O. M. is 24 years old, married and has a one-year-old son, whom they hope to educate to university level. Charles' business is located at Kachok junction in Kisumu, a strategic location along the road. He has been making menswear and selling to local men. He also sells household goods such as flour, sugar, milk and soap. He has been running this business for three years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has are financial constraints. He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy materials for making menswear and restocking his inventory of flour, sugar, soap and milk. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as hardworking, social, humble and respectful.

loans.use: to buy materials for making menswear and to restock household goods to sell

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala eastern region of Uganda.  She is single and has 1 child, who is not in school. Zaina has been operating a business selling secondhand clothes for one year. Zaina also generates additional income by running a library. To help expand her business, Zaina is requesting a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. Zaina hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to open up her second business (library). In the future, Zaina hopes to own a house.

Note to lenders:
BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to open another business (library)

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
El comité La Amistad nace mediante el deseo de las integrantes de trabajar para ayudar a sus familias y salir adelante de la mejor manera.
Algunas de las integrantes han logrado mejorar sus negocios y otras pudieron comenzar con una actividad que les pueda generar ingresos.
Una de las integrantes del comité es la señora Sonia quien se dedica a realizar trabajos  de manicura.
Ella visita a sus clientas para realizar el trabajo, y los días que mas trabaja son los sábados y ella ese día obtiene el ingreso para la semana.
De esta forma ella ayuda mucho a su marido y pudo mejorar bastante su calidad de vida.
Ella solicita el préstamo para el pago de cursos sobre manicura.
texts.en:
The La Amistad committee was born of the wish of its memebrs to work to help their familes and to get ahead in a better way. Some of the members have been able to improve their businesses and others have been able to begin an activity that can generate them income. One of the members of the commitee is Sonia, whose work is giving manicures. She visits her customers to do the work. The days she works the most are Saturdays and that day she makes her income for the week. In this way, she helps her husband a lot and has been able to improve their quality of life. She is asking for the loan to pay for manicure courses.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Payment for manicure courses .

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en: Vicent, age 27, is a married man with three children, living in his own house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He grows tea, which he has sold for four years. He has an established tea garden but faces problems of prolonged droughts which hamper the expected growth of the tea crop. Like most Ugandans, Vicent dreams of building a permanent house and educating his children. He wants a loan to purchase  green tea leaf to add to what he gets from his garden for selling.

loans.use: To purchase green tea leaf for reselling

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 45-year-old married man living in Nabatieh, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and four children. Ali is a specialized table carpenter, which he believes is an art in itself. Ali is recommended for his high quality of work as a carpenter and designer by many furniture showrooms. This is Ali’s fourth cycle with Al Majmoua with a good repayment record.

Ali has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy extra wood to increase his designs and income. At the same time, Ali believes that he has to stay up-to-date with global designs to capture new customers and maintain his level or advance to a better one. He hopes to be known all over Lebanon and improve his machines in the future.

loans.use: To buy extra wood

loans.name: Slivia

texts.en:
Slivia N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala eastern region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, 2 of whom are in school. Slivia has been running a business selling snacks such as sausages for one year. To help expand her business, Slivia is requesting a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda, which will be used to buy more meat. Slivia hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to expand her business. In the future, Slivia hopes to open up another business such as cosmetics.

Note to lenders:
BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more meat

loans.name: Ebenezer #5 Group

texts.en:
Samuel P., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Ebenezer #5.

He is 32 years old, single and has one child who is 14 years old. He was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to financial difficulty.   

For 8 years, he has been selling phone cards on Broad Street in Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 17,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 77,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more phone cards. 

He describes himself as an easy-going man. His goal is to grow his business and continue his education.

loans.use: To buy more phone cards.

loans.name: Clive Road Womens Group A -Jinja

texts.en: To achieve any kind of flood tide of success in any business, constant planning measures are needed. As a result of 29 year old W. Justine’s good blueprint plans for her 2 year old clothing sales business, she now has a settled means of subsistence. She has succeeded in making profitable use of her short time in business. If comparisons are drawn with her previous source of income-being a cook, all the signs are evident that she has come a long way. The odds of her making more profits in the future are looking good given the 30,000 she makes in a week as profits notwithstanding the competition she faces from other business people. This high spirited single mother of 2 school going children is holding her head high with optimism that with this loan, she will be in a better position to buy more bales of clothes for resell.

loans.use: the buying of more bales of clothes for resell

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 40 year old man from Nabatieh, Southern Lebanon. Mohamad lives with his wife and single kid. Mohamad works in construction; he is specialized in digging lands and roads. Mohamad has seven years of experience in this domain, he has a poclain and a bobcat machines to do such kind of work. This is Mohamad’s Fifth cycle with Al Majmoua, he requested a loan in order to buy new wheels to the bobcat and make the necessary maintenance to his machines. His clients are anyone possible, because there is a lot of request for this kind of work. Ali hopes to own a bulldozer in the future in order to increase & improve his family income and level.

loans.use: To buy new wheels to the bobcat and make the necessary maintenance to his machines

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace wants a loan to clear more land and purchase tea plantlets to expand her tea plantation. In her area, most people rely on tea planting for survival and they have managed to improve tea productivity in Uganda as a whole. She has been in the tea-growing business for 10 years and dreams of becoming a model farmer. Grace started with a small garden that has grown over the years. Like any other farmer, Grace faces the problem of pests and weeds. 

At the age of 32, Grace has four children between the ages of 11 and 2 years old. They live in Kyenjojo, Uganda.

loans.use: To clear more land and purchase tea plantlets to expand her tea plantation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food items.

loans.name: Clive Road  Women's Group B-Jinja

texts.en: If you carry yourself around with the courage of your convictions and confidence in tow, you are likely to make head way in whatever you get your hands on or in whatever business you bear a hand in. At least that is the reality 40 year old Z. Kate has been in touch with for the past 10 years in her clothes sells business in Jinja. She exemplified all the above qualities at the threshold of her business 10 years ago. The business was thrown into gear with a loan she got, combined with savings from her former poultry business. Hard work, perseverance and determination she says have been her stocks in trade. Her business at present generates for her 60,000 shillings on a weekly basis as profits. With this loan, she wants to buy more bales of clothes for resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more bales of clothes for resell both new and second hand clothes.

loans.name: Yasimi

texts.en: Yasimi S. is currently in the business of selling bags of peeled dried cassava and maize at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of sorghum to sell. Yasimi is 45 years old and widowed. She has 6 children, who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: Stock bags of sorghum to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 51-year-old man from Lebanon, married with 7 children. Ali has owned a grocery store for 10 years. This is Ali’s first time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua. He plans to use the loan to buy extra refreshments (cold soft drinks) for the summer season to increase his store’s goods and income. This helps to improve his family's income. Ali’s dream is to own a bigger grocery store in the future, which will provide a good income for his seven children, whom he hopes will work with him to improve the business.

loans.use: To buy extra refreshments (cold soft drinks) for the summer season

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is a married woman, age 38, with two children. She lives in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda, in a semi permanent house with  six other people. She has been doing tailoring and designing for 3 years. She started as a tailor in someone else's shop but now owns her own. She wants a loan to buy clothes for her tailoring business and to resell them.

loans.use: Buying clothes for tailoring and reselling

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en: Mouhamad is a 30-year-old man from Lebanon, working as a blacksmith for three years. Mouhamad has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy an important steel welding machine, which is necessary for his work and makes it easier. This is Mouhamad’s third cycle with Al Majmoua,and he has proved to be an honest person through his repayment schedule. Mouhamad believes that this machine can improve his work and expand his working region. He hopes to cover his region as much as he can and to be known by all as a man with professional work. Mouhamad hopes to have a small family that is educated and to never fear the future.

loans.use: To buy an important steel welding machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase ingredients & supplies for preparing her dishes

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala eastern region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.  Rehema has operated a business selling food (matooke) for less than one year. Matooke is a meal consisting of steamed green banana and is one of the national dishes of Uganda. To help expand her business, Rehema is requesting a loan of 150,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda, which she will use to buy more matooke. Rehema hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to expand in her business. In the future, Rehema hopes to see her children study up to university.

Note to lenders:
BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more matooke for selling

loans.name: Geltulde

texts.en:
Geltulde is 29 years old and married with two children who are 4 and 6 years old. Geltulde is well known for her business selling a variety of goods in her shop. She has owned a shop for a long time. The hours of her business are from 6 am to 9 am every day.

Geltulde needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, Geltulde will expand her business by investing in the sale of foodstuffs (beans, rice, peas, sugar, etc.) She really hopes that her revenue will increase. If successful, Geltulde will keep reinvesting in her business for better financial stability and for taking care of her family.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods, mainly foodstuffs (beans, rice, peas, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is a single parent with three children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two room house which has electricity and piped water.

Madina owns a retail shop selling all types of merchandise such as sugar, salt cooking oil, etc. She buys her merchandise from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala, and uses public transportation to and from Kampala and her shop in Kisaasi. She rents her business premises at 70,000 UGX per month and her customers are people around the area. She works seven days a week and has been in this business for the last ten years. Her business challenges are seasonality and defaulters. Madina has no additional income.

Madina wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, bags of maize flour and boxes of soap. She hopes to see her business grow big so she can earn enough profit and build her own house. Madina decided to work with MCDT in order to get additional capital for her business. She depends on this job for a living.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise such as sugar, salt, maize flour and soap

loans.name: Kamisa

texts.en: Kamisa I. is currently in the business of selling bedsheets, trousers and dresses at the market  and is requesting a loan to stock saddles and shoes to sell. Kamisa is 29 years old and is married to a driver. She has one child who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock saddles and shoes to sell

loans.name: Main Dans La Main Plus Group

texts.en:
Freddy L. is the president of the Community Bank “Main dans la main Plus”, which is composed of 13 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Freddy runs a telephone booth in his area, located east of Kinshasa. He began his business in 2000. His starting capital was $80. With hard work and determination, his business has prospered. Freddy is now well known and liked in this area. He has already received two MFI HOPE DRC loans and fully repaid them. Since that time, his business has prospered and the loans he has received have helped him rent a well-located business place. He makes $90 profit each week. Freddy intends to purchase more prepaid cards with the next loan, to meet customer demand and generate additional profits. He is 40 years old and single. His ambition is to open a cellular phone shop in his area.

loans.use: To buy more prepaid cards

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen K. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell. Hellen is 36 years old and is married, with a husband who is a business man. She has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes and onions to sell.

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not in school. Milly has a business selling phone air time, which she has had for two years.

To help expand her business, Milly is requesting a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more air time for selling. Milly hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to add more capital to her business. In the future, Milly hopes to open up another business (a saloon).

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive micro-finance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional micro-finance.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in micro-finance.

loans.use: To buy more phone air time.

loans.name: Clive Road Womens Group C-Jinja

texts.en: She is an example of a successful, hardworking woman, who has succeeded in living within her monthly profits of 500,000 shillings for the past nine years in Jinja. Nine years maintaining a successful business makes one a past master at making good decisions aimed at consolidating and reinforcing one's gains. Twenty-eight-year-old Monica M. started off small in her banana sales business, but her beginnings are something she now sees in perspective, given the progress she has made. She has her own stall in Jinja central market. Her clients are mostly the lowest common denominator, who stay around the central market area where she operates. Monica is married, with four children, of whom three are in school. With this loan, she wants to buy more bananas for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas for resale.

loans.name: Las Amigas Group

texts.es:
Todas las integrantes del comité están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya por el valioso apoyo que les brinda para poder mejorar sus condiciones financieras en la sociedad.
La señora Juana es una de las integrantes y se dedica a la fabricación y venta de chipas.
Ella dos a tres veces a la semana dependiendo de las ventas elabora las chipas y los lleva hasta el centro de la ciudad donde están sus clientes mayoristas y también individuales.
Todo el trabajo lo realiza con la ayuda de su marido y sus hijos, así ello se trabajan mutuamente para salir adelante.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de ingrediente para la elaboración de chipas, como almidón, grasa, queso, leche, harina de maíz y otros.
texts.en:
All of the members of the committee are very grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya for the valuable support it has offered them to be able to improve their financial conditions in society. Juana is one of the members and she makes and sells chipas. Two or three times a week, depending on sales, she makes the chipas and takes them downtown where she has wholesale and individual customers. She does all of the work with her husband and children and in this way they work together to get ahead. She is asking for the loan to purchase ingredients, such as starch, lard, cheese, milk, corn meal and others.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy starch, lard, cheese, milk, corn meal and others.

loans.name: Discipline Plus Group

texts.en:
“Discipline Plus” is a group of 28 owners of small businesses chaired by Lucien K.. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva through MFI HOPE DRC.

Lucien started a cigarette-selling business in 1997 with a capital investment of $25. After he went bankrupt because of theft, he decided to open a general boutique, which he continues to operates today. With hard work and determination, his business has prospered. 

Lucian is happy to be part of one of Hope’s groups. He joined the group in November 2009 and his business has been reinforced through the loan he received. Lucien intends to use this loan to purchase cans and other miscellaneous items to increase the inventory of his boutique in order to increase his profit. 

Lucien is 36 years old and has two children, ages 4 and 10.  Currently, Lucien makes a profit of about $100 per week. His dream is to open a sea transport enterprise someday. His general boutique is located in the western area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. Rebecca also takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall where she sells second-hand clothing and shoes in Owino market, which is one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Rebecca wants to use this loan to buy more bales of men’s clothing. She has no other source of additional income. 

Rebecca has been in this business for the last 10 years. She works six days a week. One of her biggest business challenges is the rainy season because she works from an open place. Rebecca aspires to see her business grow big and to start importing clothes herself.  She decided to work with MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting additional capital.  

She resides in a  rented two-room house which has electricity and piped water. Her greatest expenses are school fees, rent, and food.

loans.use: To buy more bales of men's clothing

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha G. is a 50-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a weaving  business. She lives in the municipality of Bogo, Argao, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions through her own hard work and with the help of her loans from NWTF. 

By working hard in her  weaving  business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9600. Editha is now borrowing PHP 16000 to add to her working capital. This is her ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15000, which she repaid well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Editha wants to improve her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
