María del Pilar es una madre de familia de 38 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus tres hijos en el sector el Huabal, un centro poblado perteneciente al distrito de Chepén, una zona agrícola de movimiento comercial moderado, pertenece a la provincia del mismo nombre y se encuentra ubicada en la Región La Libertad, a una hora y cuarenta y cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a trabajar en actividades relacionadas con la agricultura, ella cuenta con un terreno de cultivo en donde suele sembrar diversos granos y cereales, como maíz y arroz, su familia depende de esta actividad para mantener gran parte de su economía, por lo que siempre cuida de sus cultivos para que estos puedan brindarle una excelente producción.

En esta oportunidad ella ha sembrado maíz en su terreno, María desea brindarle mantenimiento aplicándole algunos fertilizantes, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le permitan realizar esta acción.

María del Pilar siempre se esfuerza al máximo para sacar adelante a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es seguir trabajando para poder brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
María del Pilar, 38, is a mother living with her husband and three children in Huabal, a population center in Chepén district, an agricultural area with moderate commercial activity. It belongs to Chepén province, La Libertad region located an hour and forty-five minutes from the city of Chiclayo, Lambayeque region’s capital. She is a farmer. She has a field where she grows various grains and cereals like corn and rice. Her family depends on this activity for a large part of their economy. Therefore, she always cares for her crops so that they will yield the best possible production. On this occasion she has planted corn in her field. María wants to care for it adding fertilizer. She has found it convenient, therefore, to request her first, 2000 new sol, loan from Edpyme Alternativa to reach this goal. María del Pilar always puts maximum effort into her family’s success. Her greatest wish is to continue working to provide her family with a better quality of life. .

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her corn crops.

loans.name: Roza's Group

texts.en:
Roza B., 56, is happy to be leading this wonderful group of borrowers located in Toktogul. The office in Toktogul recently started working with Kiva, so Roza’s Group is one of the first Kiva loans here. Roza is married with one 23-year-old son. Her son is a student and her husband works in the Registry Department of the state. Roza wants to use her loan to complete the construction of a store. She has already begun the process, but she needs more materials, and needs to hire help. Once the store is built, Roza plans to set up her business.

Roza has three partners:

Alchabu K., 42, is married and has two sons and a daughter—15, 10, and 6 respectively. All her children study at school. Four years ago Alchabu started selling convenience goods. At first, she had to rent a kiosk to sell her goods, but later on she was able to purchase it and expand her business. Her initial investment was 3000 soms and today she makes a profit of 5000 per month. She wants to use this loan to purchase more goods to increase the selection of goods at her kiosk. Alchabu dreams of opening a big store some day.

Seidimambet T., a widower, is 59 years old. He has one son and two daughters: 23, 21, and 13 respectively. Seidimambet’s work is to transport goods by carts carried by livestock, he also breeds livestock. Three years ago, with 5000 soms, Seidimambet purchased livestock for breeding—with that profit he bought a donkey then made a cart and began transporting goods in this way. Today he makes a 3000 monthly profit. With this loan Seidimambet plans to purchase more livestock for breeding, he wishes to increase the number of cattle he owns.

Member Batma T. is a 53-year-old married woman with one daughter and one son—both 21. Her children are students and her husband is retired—he often helps her breeding livestock. Batma’s principal job is working as a phone operator; she has been doing this for five years. Some time ago, Batma took out a loan in order to purchase livestock. With her profits, Batma was able to pay for her son’s university education. She would like to use this loan to buy more cattle so that she can make a larger profit and contribute to her son’s wedding.

loans.use: To complete the construction of a store

loans.name: Elsa Normina

texts.es:
Elsa es una madre de familia de 33 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el sector Pacanguilla del distrito de Pacanga, un distrito eminentemente agrícola que pertenece a la provincia de Chepén,ubicada en la región La Libertad, a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica al alquiler de habitaciones, ella cuenta con cinco habitaciones en su domicilio, las cuales alquila a los trabajadores de la zona, este negocio le permite ayudar a su esposo con el sostenimiento de la economía de su familia. El trabaja como capataz en una empresa agrícola de la zona. Juntos tratan de salir adelante y progresar.

Elsa desea arreglar algunas habitaciones para asi poder brindarle a sus inquilinos mayor comodidad, para lograr este objetivo está solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Elsa es una mujer trabajadora y entregada a su familia, su mayor anhelo es seguir trabajando para apoyar a su esposo y darle a su familia la oportunidad de gozar una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Elsa is 33 years old. She lives with her husband and their two children in the Pacanguilla sector in the Pacanga district. This is mostly a farming district, which belongs to the Chepén province. It is located in the La Libertad region. It is one hour from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region. She rents rooms, and she has five rooms for rent in her home. She rents them to workers in the area. This business allows her to help her husband support her family. Her husband works as a foreman in an agricultural company in the area. Together they try to get ahead and make progress. She wishes to fix up some of the rooms in order to be able to provide her renters with greater comfort. To achieve this objective she is requesting a loan, for the first time, for 1,000 soles from Edpyme Alternativa. Elsa is a hard-working woman, and she is devoted to her family. Her greatest desire is to keep working to help her husband and to give her family the opportunity to enjoy a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fix up rooms in order to rent them

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To but material to repair the roof (zinc, timber, nails and labour costs)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fruit, milk, sugar, disposible cups and spoons

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cosmetics, creams, and tools to use in her beauty salon

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a 33-year-old man living in Bundibugyo, Uganda, with his wife and four children. His wife is a hairdresser and together they live in a rented house nursing a dream of constructing their own residential home in the near future.

Robert operates a salon which provides services for both men and women. He has been in the business for two years now, having sold charcoal as his first business activity. He notes, however, that machine breakdowns are affecting the operation of the business. He hopes to see his business grow in size and improve the quality of services offered.

Robert intends to use the loan to buy hairdryers for the ladies’ side of the salon and also shampoo and creams.

loans.use: To buy hairdryers for the ladies' side of the salon and also shampoo and creams

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sow 3.5 acres of plantains, maintenence and cleaning of 3.5 acres of plantains, for a total of 7 acres.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a single mother of four children aged 15, 13, 10 and 8 years. Ester lives in Bundibugyo, Uganda in the semi-permanent house shown in the picture. She is the head of her family and is responsible for the welfare and education of her children and her two brothers who live with her.

"It’s a big task," she says, but she hopes to succeed by seeing them through. 

Ester operates a clothing shop in which she sells clothes, bags, and mattresses. She has operated this business for the last four years. Previously, she sold cocoa, a major cash crop in her area. 

The purpose of the loan is to enable Ester to purchase clothes, bags and mattresses to sell in her shop. She says that, with more capital, she will be able to offer her products wholesale to retailers.

loans.use: To buy clothes, bags and mattresses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy tools to speed up his work (repairing air conditioners)

loans.name: Ideal Group

texts.es:
El grupo ideal lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras, esforzadas y emprendedoras originarias de Masaya ciudad de las flores donde su economía se basa en la agricultura y hay una gran expresión cultura y arte.
La coordinadora del grupo es Thelma Gómez quien en 1980 inicio vender de  forma ambulante en el mercado de Masaya unas cuantas frutas y verduras, actualmente tiene su propio  tramo  y con el préstamo piensa comprar mayor cantidad de productos.
Las otras integrantes del grupo son Tania Gómez G. de 21 años quien acaba de iniciar su negocio de bordado y costuras con el préstamo invertirá en materiales como hilos y telas, y  Irene Gómez G. desde hace siete años comercializa ropa típica.
texts.en:
The Ideal group is composed of three hard working, dedicated, enterprising women from Masaya, city of flowers, whose economy is based on agriculture and where there is a great cultural and artistic expression. The group coordinator is Thelma Gómez who started selling fruits and vegetables in Masaya's market in 1980. She started out as an itinerant seller but now has her own stall and will use the funds to buy a larger amount of merchandise. The other group members are: Tania Gómez G., 21, who has just started her embroidery and sewing business. She’ll use the funds to buy supplies like fabric and thread and Irene Gómez Gonzáles who has sold typical clothing for the last 7 years.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For fruit and vegetables.

loans.name: Exito Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Éxito lo conforman tres personas trabajadoras, estordas y emprendedoras una de ellas es Araceli U. quien desde hace ocho años vende cosmético de diferentes marcas. Ella tiene dos hijos de 14 y 8 años por los cuales trabaja arduamente.
Las otras integrantes son Yolanda N. quien produce y comercializa tiste, pozol, pinolillo etc. y María Magdalena U. M. quien es costurera desde hace 20 años.
texts.en:
The El Éxito (Success) group is made up of three hard working, dedicated and enterprising people. One of them is Araceli U. who has sold various brands of cosmetics for the last 8 years. She has two children, who are 14 and 8 years of age, for whom she works hard. The other group members are: Yolanda N. who makes and sells tiste (drink made with tortilla, cacao and sugar), pozol (drink made with corn and cacao), pinolillo (cornmeal and cacao-based drink), etc. and María Magdalena U. M. who has been a seamstress for the last 20 years.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For cosmetics.

loans.name: San Patricio Group

texts.es:
El grupo San Patricio está conformado por tres féminas emprendedoras, luchadoras y esforzadas originarias de Masaya ciudad de las flores donde su economía se basa en la agricultura. Ellas se dedican al comercio de perecederos en el mercado de Masaya.
La coordinadora del grupo es Paulina Bermúdez de 47 años quien desde 1990 se dedica al comercio de verduras y tiene una pequeña venta en su casa. Las otras integrantes son Francisca U. quien compra y vende frutas negocio en el que lleva 36 años y Juana Paula Rodríguez comercializa papaya y naranjas.
texts.en:
The San Patricio (Saint Patrick) group is composed of three enterprising, hard working and dedicated women from Masaya, city of flowers, whose economy is based on agriculture. They are foodstuffs merchants in Masaya’s market. The group coordinator is Paulina Bermúdez, 47, who has sold vegetables since 1990 and has a small store in her home. The other members are: Francisca U. who has sold fruits and vegetables for 36 years and Juana Paula Rodríguez who sells oranges and papayas.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: María Isabel Group

texts.es:
El grupo María Isabel está conformado por tres mujeres trabajadoras, esforzadas y emprendedoras una ellas es la señora Irenia del Carmen L. quienes venden frutas y verduras desde la edad de 15 años. L. tiene cinco hijos de los cuales los dos menores de 18 y 16 años dependen de ella.
Las otras integrantes del grupo son Thelma R. Jiménez quien vende pan desde hace 10 años y Jessenia Marcías Gonzales quien vende fajas y CD desde el 2006.
texts.en:
The María Isabel group is made up of three hard working, dedicated, enterprising women. One of them is Mrs. Irenia del Carmen L. who has sold fruits and vegetables since she was 15 years old. She has five children. The two youngest, who are 18 and 16 years of age, are still dependent on her. The other group members are: Thelma R. Jiménez who has sold bread for the last 10 years and Jessenia Marcías Gonzáles who has sold sashes and CDs since 2006.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonal crops.

loans.name: Xiomara Group

texts.es:
El grupo Xiomara lo integran tres féminas esforzadas, emprendedoras y trabajadoras originarias de Masaya ciudad de las flores donde su economía se basa en la agricultura. La coordinadora es la señora Rosa Esther M., comerciante de frutas y verduras desde hace cinco años el cual desea mejorar y progresar por ello invertirá el crédito en su negocio.

 Las otras integrantes del grupo son Maribel del Carmen Silva vende frutas y María Magdalena Canon también comercializa perecederos desde hace varios años.
texts.en:
The Xiomara group is composed of three dedicated, enterprising and hard working women who are from Masaya, city of flowers, whose economy is based on agriculture. The group coordinator is Mrs. Rosa Esther M. who has been a fruit and vegetable merchant for five years. She hopes to improve and grow so will invest the loan in her business. The other group members are: Maribel del Carmen Silva who sells fruit and María Magdalena Canon who has also sold perishable items for several years.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy crops.

loans.name: Pradera Group

texts.es:
El grupo Pradera lo integran cuatro mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es la señora Tania Auxiliadora A. de 22 años quien produce y vende calzado desde hace cinco años con ayuda de sus padres y su hermano con el cual se distribuye el trabajo. Ella sueña con tener un taller que preste las condiciones necesarias.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son Eugenia G. quien tiene una pulpería y  Elisabeth  C. que se dedica al comercio de leña y nacatamales, comida típica a base de masa y cerdo.
texts.en:
The Pradera (Meadow) group is composed of three hard working women. One of them is Mrs. Tania Auxiliadora A., 22, who has manufactured shoes, with help from her parents, for the last five years to sell with help from her brother. She dreams with having a well-conditioned workshop. The other group members are: Eugenia G. who has a grocery store and Elisabeth C. who sells firewood and nacatamales, a typical dish made of pork stuffed dough.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For materials like leather, adhesive, soles, etc.

loans.name: San Sebastian Group

texts.es:
El grupo San Sebastián está conformado por tres mujeres ejemplares una de ellas es Erika C. quien desde joven se dediaca a la producion y comercio de buñuelos dulces tradicionales hechos a base de yuca, queso y miel. Ella tiene ocho hijos de los cuales solo dependen de ellas siete de 19.18, 17,14, 11,8 y 3 años de los cuales dos de ellos no estudian la pequeña y la niña de 11con capacidades diferentes. 
Las otras integrantes son Onelia Dávila que se dedica desde hace diez años a la realización de bordados y Miguelina M. quien tiene una zapatería desde hace 15 años.
texts.en:
The group San Sebastián is made up of three exemplary women. One of them is Ericka C. who has been making and selling "buñuelos" (traditional candies made of yucca, cheese and honey) since she was young. Ericka has eight children of whom seven are dependen on her. Their ages are 19, 18, 17, 14, 11, 8 and 3. Her youngest child is not in school and her 11 year old is also not in school because she has special needs. The other members of the group are Onelia Dávila who has been doing embroidery for ten years and Miguelina M. who has had a shoe store for 15 years.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase yuca, cheese and honey

loans.name: Aguacate Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Aguacate está conformado por Silvia del Carmen L. G. quien vende ropa y comida desde hace cuatro años con el propósito de que sus dos hijas tengan un mejor futuro en especial su educación es que la mejor herencia que les puede dar.

Las otras integrantes son Eloisa L. G. quien comercializa ropa y Blanca Carolina Humbes Cruz comerciante de calzado y ropa desde varios años.
texts.en:
The “Aguacate” (Avocato) group includes Silvia del Carmen L. G., who’s been selling food and clothing for the past four years. She does this so that her two children will have a better future, especially a good education, which is the best inheritance she can give them. The other members are Eloisa L. G., who sells clothing, and Blanca Carolina Humbes Cruz, who has been selling shoes and clothing for several years.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing for resale

loans.name: Vida Y Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El grupo Vida y Esperanza está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras y esforzadas una de ellas es Rosa Amanda C. Ríos quien comercializa productos lácteos desde hace ocho años con poco pero con los créditos su negocio ha salido adelante. Ella tiene cuatro hijos  de 21, 19,17 y 12 los cuales estudian.
Las otras integrantes son Martha Francisca M.  comerciante de cosméticos y Clemente José E. vende granos básico.
texts.en:
The “Vida y Esperanza” (Life and Hope) group is made up of three hard working people. One of them is Rosa Amanda C. Ríos. She’s been selling milk products for the past eight years. Her business has moved ahead thanks to the loans she has received. She has four children, ages 21, 19, 17, and 12, all of whom attend school. The other members of the group are Martha Fransisca M., who sells cosmetics, and Clemente José E., who sells basic grains.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ingredients

loans.name: Repollito Group

texts.es:
El grupo repollito lo conforman Erwin T., Juana G. y Jessenia E. tres personas trabajadoras y esforzadas. La coordinadora del Grupo doña Juana G. desde hace 15 años se dedica a la elaboración y comercio de pasteles de piña, queso y pollo.
Los otros integrantes Erwing T. tiene un pequeño taxi el cual da mantenimiento y  Jessenia E. se dedica al comercio de queso. Ellos con el préstamo desean mejorar su negocio y seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The "Repollito" group includes Erwin T., Juana G. and Jessenia E.. They are three hardworking and dedicated people. The coordinator of the group is Juana G.. She has been making and selling pastries filled with pineapple, cheese and chicken for 15 years. The other members have different activities: Erwing Trana has a small taxi which she maintains, and Jessenia E. sells cheese. With this loan they want to improve their businesses and get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy flour, eggs, cheese, chicken, pineapple, etc.

loans.name: Ebenezer Group

texts.es:
El grupo Ebenezer está conformado por mujeres trabajadoras, esforzadas y emprendedoras una de ellas es Raquel Esther D., quien tiene una pequeña panadería en la que produce diferentes tipos de pan, dulce, con queso…etc. 
 Las otras integrantes son Bertha L. quien se dedica al comercio de ropa desde hace varios años y María de los Ángeles P. comerciantes de cosméticos.
texts.en:
The "Ebenezer" group is made up of women who are hardworking, dedicated and enterprising. One of these is Raquel Esther D., who has a small bakery where she produces different types of bread, sweets, pastries with cheese, etc. The other members are Bertha Lopez, who has been selling clothing for a number of years, and María de los Ángeles P., who sells cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Havila Group

texts.es:
El grupo Havilas lo conforman Yahoska M., Olga R. y Ana María C. tres féminas trabajadoras, esforzadas y emprendedoras. La coordinadora es M. comerciante de ropa usada y nueva negocio que inicio hace dos años.
Las otras integrantes Olga R. comercializa cosméticos de distintas marcas y Ana María C. tiene una pequeña fritanga restaurante popular que consiste en comida frita y vende ropa.
texts.en:
The "Havilas" group is formed by Yahoska M., Olga R. and Ana María C., three dedicated, hardworking and enterprising women. The coordinator is M., who sells new and used clothing, a business that she started 2 years ago. The other members are Olga R., who sells a variety of brands of cosmetics, and Ana Maria C., who has a small restaurant where she sells fried food and also sells clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Compartimos Group

texts.es:
El grupo Compartimos lo integran tres féminas emprendedoras y esforzadas este es su primer crédito en Adim con el cual esperan progresar. La coordinadora es  María Elsa O. comerciante ambulante de pan por las tardes y en la mañana lava y plancha tarea difícil y dura.
Las otras integrantes son Angélica María L. Gaitán quien vende leña y Diana Leticia O. Mendoza  comercializa ropa usada y cosméticos
texts.en:
The group "Compartimos" is made up of 3 enterprising and dedicated women. This is their first loan with ADIM, and with it they hope to make progress with their businesses. The coordinator is Maria Elsa O., who is a street vendor who sells bread in the afternoons, and in the morning works washing and ironing, work that is difficult and hard. The other members are Angélica María L. Gaitán, who sells firewood, and Diana Leticia O. Mendoza, who sells used clothing and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy bread, soap and detergent

loans.name: Brenda De Los Ángeles

texts.es: Brenda de los Ángeles R. A. es una joven trabajadora, esforzada, emprendedora y jovial. Ella inicio vendiendo chiverías, helados de coco, maní, coyolito y gaseosas en la actualidad desde pues de luchar mucho tiene una pequeña pulpería donde comercializa desde granos básicos, productos de limpieza, chiverías...etc.
texts.en:
Brenda de los Ángeles R. A. is a jovial youth who is hardworking, dedicated and enterprising. She started out selling snacks, ice cream flavored with coconut, peanut and coyolito (palm fruit), and soft drinks. Today, after a long struggle, she has a small grocery store where she sells staple grains, cleaning products, snacks, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy staple grains, snacks, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Edelma Elena

texts.es: Edelma Elena L. R. es una señora trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora que se dedica al comercio de frutas y verduras como papa, cebolla, piña, ayote, yuca, quequis etc. en los cuales invertirá el crédito con el propicito de salir adelante.
texts.en:
Edelma Elena L. R. is a hard working, dedicated and enterprising woman who sells fruits and vegetables, such as potatoes, onions, pineapple, squash, yucca, etc. This is where she will invest the money from this loan so that she can get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Eufemia Elizabeth

texts.es: Eufemia Elizabeth C. es una señora trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora tiene un servicio de recorrido desde hace 30 años. Ella con el crédito mejorar el transporte ya que este requiere de mantenimiento para dar seguridad y confort a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Eufemia Elizabeth C. is a dedicated, enterprising, and hard-working woman who has had a transport service for 30 years. With her loan she would like to improve her transport service since she needs to maintain her vehicle for the safety and comfort of her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Halea Meese, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle Maintenance

loans.name: Loida Del Socorro

texts.es: Loida del Socorro J. P. es una señora trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora que se dedica al comercio de ropa como camisas, camisetas, blusas, jeans, pantalones etc. Los cuales distribuye de manera ambulante por las calles de Managua.
texts.en:
Loida del Socorro J. P. is a hard working, dedicated, and enterprising woman. She sells clothing, such as shirts, t-shirts, blouses, jeans, pants, etc. She distributes these through the streets of Managua on foot.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing for resale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
The fishing business has brought pleasure to Helen’s family. Because of its profits, she has been able to support her family’s needs. Being a good mother, Helen has always wanted to support her children in whatever career they would be taking to better their own personal life.  Aside from Helen’s fishing business, financed by the loan she received from ASHI, she also has a farming business.  This is her way of saving her profits to support the needs of her family, especially to pay for her children’s education until college.

Her husband’s support of her fishing business is Helen’s inspiration to keep growing her business despite the challenges of poverty.  Over time, Helen has been able to purchase a fishing boat for her husband to manage and use for fishing.  Meanwhile, Helen is the one who sells his fish directly to people in local community and nearby town of Jala-jala, Rizal.

With that, Helen is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to purchase additional fishing equipment to catch more fish to sell and support the maintenance of her family's farming business. This would help their business grow, and make more profit, which will enable her to support her ambition in life.

Helen has been an ASHI member since 2005. Her family is very thankful that she has an opportunity to improve their standard of living through the income of the fishing and fish selling businesses she has established with the support of the loans she has requested.

The attached picture of Helen was taken July 14,2010 with her supportive husband, Jesus S. J..

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing equipment and to support the maintenance of the family farming business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase necessary materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy two new machines

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy fabric for quilts

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To enlarge his shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Tayseer

texts.en:
Tayseer, whom we see in the picture above, is a 41-year-old man from Jenin. He is the father of three sons and two daughters. Tayseer and his sons work the land, growing and selling vegetables. However, this business is not providing enough income for the father to pay for the household expenses and his children's education. 

Tayseer decided to start another business where one of the sons could work and help him. One of Tayseer's sons was trained to repair mobile phones, so Tayseer rented a small shop for this business. He took a loan from FATEN to purchase the tools used to repair mobile phones and the exhibition stands used to display them in the shop.

loans.use: Purchase tools and display stands for a mobile phone repair shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to invest in the business and to purchase dried fruits

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en:
Josphat is 36 years old. He is married and has been blessed with two children, ages 3 and 7. His eldest child is currently attending school.

Josphat has been practicing mixed farming for fifteen years in the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. His farm produces tea, milk and poultry which he sells locally. He is also employed and operates a retail shop in the same area. His biggest challenge has been the inconsistent prices of his products and drought which affects his production.

Josphat recently completed his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of.45,000 KES and has requested this loan of 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the proceeds from this loan will help him improve his family's standard of living.

He hopes to be fully self-employed through farming in the future. He is suggesting that Juhudi should reduce the interest rate on their loans.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Cherono

texts.en:
Cherono has been operating her mixed farm for four years in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. Her farm produces pineapples, tea and milk which she sells to the local market. 

Cherono is 28 years old. She is a single mother of two children, ages 5 and 7. Both children attend school. She is a hardworking farmer and hopes that in five years time, she will have increased her land for animal feeds and other crops.

She recently completed her previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES and has requested this loan of 60,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. She believes that her income will increase through the sale of milk and she will be able to improve her family's standard of living.

Cherono says that the previous loan from Juhudi has helped her family and that through the proceeds from the sale of milk she has been able to buy land for herself.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is 24 years old, married, and has one 6-month-old child. He is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for the last four years and has employed one farmhand. His main product is milk, which he sells to the local market, and tea which he sells to the tea estate. He also earns income from his pool table business in the same area.

Hassan's biggest challenge has been lack of enough animal feed and lack of enough knowledge on animal diseases and pest control.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this loan will increase his source of income through the sale of milk and this will help him meet the needs of his family.

He would like to improve his farming in the future by acquiring a high yielding dairy cow and build a dairy unit. He is grateful to Juhudi for their support and requests more funding in the future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 36 years old, married, and has been blessed with three children between the ages of 5 and 11. All the children attend school. He is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for five years, selling his milk and tea to the local market. His major challenges have been lack of enough animal feed and diseases that attack his animals.

David has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the milk from this cow will enable him to feed his family well. In the future, he would like to increase the number of his dairy cows from the current two to four.

He is grateful and hopes to get more loans in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is 29 years old. He is the married father of two children, ages 4 and 6. Both children attend school. He is a hardworking farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for the last six years and has employed two people from his community. His farm produces tea and milk which he sells to the local market. His biggest challenge in farming has been lack of enough animal feed.

Benard has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this dairy cow will increase his source of income through the sale of milk and he will be able to pay school fees for his children.

In the future, he would like to improve his dairy farming by purchasing high yielding dairy cows and building a modern dairy unit. He is grateful to Juhudi and its partners for the good work.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Priscah

texts.en:
Employing one farm hand, Priscah has been operating her dairy farm in Kitale, Western Kenya for over 10 years. She sells her milk to the local market. Rampant bovine diseases, which are costly to treat, have been the biggest challenge in this business.

Priscah is requesting this loan of 30,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to start a poultry project. She says that the proceeds from this loan will help her educate her children to university level. In five years' time, Priscah expects to purchase a piece of land to expand her farming activities. She appreciates the fact that Juhudi has helped finance her to expand her farming activities.

Priscah is 45 years old, married and blessed with four children between 6 and 18 years of age, all attending school.

loans.use: To start a poultry project.

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en:
Josphat is a 42-year-old married father of six children between the ages of 2 and 21, all attending school. A farmer for the last seven years in Kisii town, Western Kenya, he produces maize, bananas, sugarcane and milk which he sells to the local market. He also earns income from the carpentry services he offers in the community.

Josphat has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the proceeds from this loan will help him educate his children and expand his workshop. His biggest challenges have been bovine diseases, lack of capital to expand his farming, exploitation by middlemen, and natural calamities that affect his production.

In future, Josphat would like to specialize in dairy farming by purchasing at least three more dairy cows that will produce enough milk for sale. He appeals for more help and is grateful to Juhudi for being there to assist farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more stationery for his store

loans.name: Barselisa

texts.en:
Barselisa is a young mother who aims to become successful someday by developing her farming business. Her husband works as an OFW (Overseas Contract Worker), and together they work for the future of their family. Barselisa is thankful to Kiva partner, ASHI, for the loans it has provided since 2005. Berselisa has been able to support her farm by purchasing fertilizers, rice seeds and other supplies, and hopes to further improve her crop production in the future through hard work and the continuous assistance of ASHI.
Lack of business capital encouraged Barselisa to seek the financial support of Kiva lenders. She will be glad if her loan request is granted and she will use the loan wisely by purchasing necessary agricultural supplies to maintain crop production. Her hard work and patience are her foundation in achieving a better life. In addition, the income Barselisa gets from her business is very helpful in supporting her business and sustaining the needs of her family, especially in providing school allowances for her two children.
Someday, Barselisa hopes to expand her farming business. She is glad for the secured opportunity of taking this loan and for your support and encouragement. Her long-term goal is to achieve a level of rice production so that she can give opportunity of employment to others, especially her extended relatives in her barangay (village). Berselisa hopes to maintain a long-term, sustainable farming business.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy construction materials to repair her house

loans.name: Sakhy Mohammad Mina Group

texts.en:
Frozan is a member of Sakhy M. Mina Group. She lives in 10th district of Kabul, Afghanistan, and is married with four children who are school students.

Frozan has a small beauty salon where she works to support her four children and cover the expense of their school fees as well. She has requested the loan to purchase cosmetics and some required chairs for her salon.

Frozan desires to continue her career and to expand her business in a better way.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and chairs for her salon

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more bead-working materials

loans.name: Saint Joseph Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SAINT JOSEPH est créé depuis trois ans. Il est composé de 11 femmes. Elles sont toutes membres de l’Association des femmes Catholiques de la Paroisse de Louga. Elles sont de la même communauté ecclésiale de base. Elles sont très impliquées dans les activités de la paroisse et participent ainsi à la vie de la communauté.
Madame Émilie C., debout à l’extrême droite de la photo, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 39 ans, mariée et mère de 04 enfants et aussi tutrice d’un enfant. 
Elle gère à domicile un kiosque où elle vend du savon en poudre, des biscuits, du savon en morceaux, du sucre, du thé etc. elle mène cette activité depuis 06 ans
Avec son nouveau prêt elle va renforcer son kiosque en marchandises énumérées ci-dessus. 
Cette activité lui procure des bénéfices qui lui permettent de renforcer son niveau d’épargne et de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
The St. Joseph solidarity group was formed three years ago. It is made up of 11 women, all members of the Association of Catholic Women of Louga parish and basically all members of the same church community. They are very involved in parish activity and thus in the life of the community. Mme Emilie C., standing at far right in the photo, leads the group. She is 39, married with four children of her own and the guardian of another. She has a stall from which she sells detergent, cookies, bar soap, sugar cubes, tea and so forth. She has been in this business for six years. With her new loan she plans to build her inventory. Her business income allows her to save more and to provide for her needs.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cookies, sugar. detergent, bar soap, etc...

loans.name: Yuliya

texts.en:
Yuliya is married. She runs a small business selling fish and sea products at one of the open markets in Berdyansk town. Yuliya has been in this business for six years. Her products are always fresh and a good quality, which is why Yuliya has many regular clients who buy from her. She enjoys her business and wants to develop it further.

Yuliya would like to borrow 8,000 UAH to purchase more inventory for her business. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her business conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married with two children. She is an entrepreneur from Uzhgorod. Olena sells children's clothing in one of the local markets. She launched her business five years ago. Currently, she earns 5,000 UAH of net profit each month. 

Olena is seeking a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase additional merchandise for her kiosk. She typically will buy inventory wholesale from her suppliers for retail sale. This allows her to maintain an adequate amount of inventory on hand and to easily update her product selection if an item is selling well or not moving quickly enough. The current loan will continue to benefit Olena's business and provide much needed income for her and her family.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is a small business owner from Kamenka. He sells food items in the local market (e.g., cereal, canned food, tea, coffee, etc.). His merchandise is priced affordably, which attracts many potential customers to his kiosk. Many Ukrainian families try to cut their budgets and save on shopping expenses. Yuryi's reasonable pricing policy and good quality groceries have kept him in business for seven years. Currently, he has about 60,000 UAH in inventory. His net profit amounts to 6,000 UAH a month. 

Yuryi is requesting a loan of 8,221 UAH to purchase additional merchandise for his kiosk to meet growing customer demand. As Yuryi has clients with different incomes, he is trying to re-stock his inventory and offer a variety of groceries in different price ranges. He is hoping to continue growing his business and keeping it sustainable despite any economic challenges.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan is married with two children. He is a businessman from Uzhgorod. Ivan sells backpacks and hiking gear. He owns a vending kiosk in the local market. Ivan has his own clients. He has been in this business for three years. Currently, Ivan makes 5,000 UAH of net profit a month. 

Ivan is seeking a loan of 10,000 UAH to increase his turnover capital. Ivan is financially reliable. His business has proven to be stable and reputable. Ivan is a hard-working entrepreneur with a clear vision. He has his own business struggles, just as many other small business owners in Ukraine have due to the economic recession. However, he doesn't lose his stamina or his optimism, and he believes in a brighter future.

loans.use: To increase his turnover capital

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is divorced with one child. She sells children's clothing at several villages in the area of Styi town. Galina has been in this business for 14 years. Her monthly income is about 6,000 UAH.

Galina would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventories. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing

loans.name: Mrs. Norm Ouch Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has 19 people who live in Trapeang Dang Tuek village in Takeo province. Mrs. Norm O. is 43 years old and is a village bank president. She was selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan in various ways. Mrs. O. is a pig breeder and a cake seller while her husband, Mr. Yav Born, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land where he cultivates rice to sell to support his family. He is also a farming laborer. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. To improve her pig breeding, Mrs. Norm O. is requesting a loan to buy more piglets and to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of three children, who are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and fertilizer

loans.name: Urtnast

texts.en:
Urtnast is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a relative’s house. Her two children, ages two and seven, attend kindergarten. 

Urtnast operates a trading business at a local market. She operates a shoes sales business and purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. Sometimes she purchases her products from Beijing. Because of the high-quality products received from Beijing, the products she offers are usually better than those offered by the other sellers. Her product selection is very good and she has a great business mind. 

Since Urtnast started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and purchased her own land. She is an open and very hardworking person. She wants to build a house on her own land.

Urtnast is requesting a loan to purchase construction materials to build a house and also to increase current assets in her business.

loans.use: To build a house and to increase her current assets in her shoe business

loans.name: Mrs. Son Nou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The fifteen people of this group have selected Mrs. Son N. as the village bank president. She is 51 years old and is located in Tuol Sang Ka village, Takeo province. The members will use their portion of their loan in varied ways to support their businesses.

Mrs. Son N. and her husband, Mr. Chhuon C., are farmers who own a one-hectare (2.5-acre) plot of land they use to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Now it’s time to grow rice but they do not have enough money to support it. So, to improve their production, Mrs. Son N. is seeking a loan to bU. fertilizer and gasoline.

Mrs. Son N. is the mother of five children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory while another one is a farmer and the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline for her farm

loans.name: Mrs. Sroeun Hang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These fourteen members are villagers in Tuol Sang Ka village in Takeo province and they make up this village bank loan. Mrs. SrO. H. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their businesses in the current year.

Mrs. SrO. H., 40 years old, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare (1.25-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family living. Her husband, Mr. Heng Sor, is a fisherman.

Mrs. SrO. H. has a problem because it is time to plow her field but she does not have the money to do so. So, to improve production, she is asking for a loan to do farming.

Mrs. SrO. H. is the mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is a laborer, and the others are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To grow a rice crop

loans.name: Yon's Group

texts.en:
In Tuol Sang Ka village, Takeo province, these five people make up this group loan. The members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. Mr. Yon N. is the group leader, selected by the other members.

Mr. Yon N., 49 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Sen Sem, are farmers who own a one-hectare (2.5-acre) plot of land that they use to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Moreover, Mr. Yon N. is also a chef.

Their problem is that is time to grow rice on their field but they do not have enough money to support doing so. So, to improve production, Mr. Yon N. is asking for a loan to do farming this current year.

Mr. Yon N. is the father of two children, one of whom is a security guard, while the other is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To grow a rice crop

loans.name: Freddie

texts.en: Freddie C.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. He is 40 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Manaoag. Freddie has been in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Freddie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise. This will be his eighth loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise

loans.name: Mrs. Nao Set Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These sixteen people are villagers in Chambak Tuem village in Takeo province and they make up this village bank loan. Mrs. N. S., who is 50 years old, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of their loan in varied ways.

Mrs. N. S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family living. Moreover, she also finds firewood to sell.

Mrs. N. S.’s problem is that her field has infertile soil and also has a lot of insects. So, to improve production, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. With the rest of the loan she will buy three piglets to raise to start a new business.

Mrs. N. S. is a widow with a child who is a fruit seller.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and to buy three piglets to raise

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia L. is from Ambalatungan, Santiago City. She is 38 years old. Patricia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Patricia owns & operates a business raising pigs to fatten and sell. Patricia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Patricia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Patricia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Patricia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily M. is from the village of Minante 2, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Emily is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns & operates a business selling personal use and home use products in the local community. She has also been selling processed foods for two months now. Emily has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emily joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emily from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna C. is from the village of Olango. She is 50 years old. Lorna is married and has 10 school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna raises livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Lorna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Rehana Begum

texts.en: Rehana Begum lives in the city of Lahore which is famous for its gardens and history in Pakistan. Rehana is a housewife who stays at home and does her household chores. She is a very responsible woman who works very hard to provide comfort to her family. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He drives a rickshaw on a rental basis. His income is reasonably good but he has to pay 40% of his income to the rickshaw owner as rent. Rehana Begum wants to help her husband to purchase his own rickshaw. She hopes that by purchasing his own rickshaw, her husband will be able to increase his income because it will minimize his cost of rent plus he will be able to work for longer periods of time with his brand new auto rickshaw.

loans.use: To purchase a new rickshaw.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson A. is from the city of Ambalatungan Santiago. He is 24 years old. Wilson is single. To make a living, Wilson owns & operates a business venture operating a motorcycle-transport tricycle. Wilson has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Wilson joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Wilson is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services that he provides. This will be the first loan taken out by Wilson from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen D. is from the village of Cabisera 5, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Helen is widowed and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Helen raises crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Helen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta E. is from the village of Olango. She is 46 years old. Roberta is married and has 7 children who are in school-aged and infant-aged. To make a living, Roberta owns & operates a business venture raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Roberta has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP monthly for this activity.

In 2010, Roberta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Roberta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Mrs. Yit Som Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has sixteen people who are located in Doun Pheu village in Takeo province. They have selected Mrs. Yit S., who is 44 years old, as the village bank president.

Mrs. Yit S. is a basket maker who sells her baskets to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Yeng OU., is a construction worker and he is also a farmer who owns a one-hectare (2.5-acre) plot land that he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Mrs. Yit S.’s problem is that her husband’s field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she plans to buy two piglets to raise to start a new business.

Mrs. Yit S. is the mother of five children, one of whom is a construction worker, while the others are studying in the local public school and are also helping with their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer plus two piglets to raise

loans.name: Munawar

texts.en:
Munawar lives in an area of Lahore called Ismail Nagar in Pakistan.  She lives in a two-story house; the first floor is rented out. At this time, when the cost of living is getting higher and higher, she is always ready to help her husband meet the financial needs of the family. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the market. He is out of stock these days, which is affecting his image and business. Due to the unavailability of stock, he is losing his customers, which is not good for his business growth. 

Munawar mentioned that if her husband doesn't earn any income in a single day, Munawar has to use the money she receives from her renters. In this way, she can’t save any money.  Therefore, Munawar has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband with his grocery shop. She is hopeful that her husband will be able to re-establish his business and generate a good income so she can save money for rainy days.

loans.use: To buy more stock to re-establish the grocery shop

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel U. is from the village of Annayatan, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 33 years old. Maribel is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel is starting to run a general store where she will be selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Maribel is just starting this business.

Maribel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Maribel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Meang

texts.en: Meang S., 41, is a widow who lives in Takeo province with her two children. She makes about US$3.50 daily, weaving silk clothes and growing vegetables. One of her child is employed as a construction worker, making US$2. She is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase more silk to weave more clothes. She is also hoping to purchase a pig, to raise and sell, with the money from the loan. She sees this loan as a great opportunity to expand her business and she is confident that she will see her income increase as a result.

loans.use: To purchase more silk.

loans.name: Rehana Kosar

texts.en:
Rehana Kosar lives in an area called Ismail Nagar which is located in the city Lahore in Pakistan. There, she has a two-roomed brick house where she lives with her family. 

Rehana is a vigorous lady. She runs a boutique from her home. Her daughter assists her in her work. She takes orders from her community and fulfills them to earn an income. She imports clothes from Faisalabad which is famous for its textile industry. Then, she offers the services of sewing and applying good designs on the clothes to her customers which gives the clothes good presentation and variety and helps her to attract more customers.  

Rehana wants to expand her business on larger scale. She sells her variety of clothes in different boutiques as well as from her home. This can only happen when she buys more material, such as clothes, laces and beads, in bulk. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah.  She is hopeful that, with the loan amount, she will be able to expand her business. This will result in an increase of her monthly income and it will increase her customer base as well.

loans.use: To purchase materials and supplies for boutique business.

loans.name: Crescelinda

texts.en:
Crescelinda G. is from the village of Minante 2, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Crescelinda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Crescelinda owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Crescelinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP every four months.

In 2007, Crescelinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Crescelinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Mrs. Roem Yeak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These nineteen people, who live in Doun Pheu village in Takeo province, make up this village bank loA.. They have selected Mrs. Roem Y., who was born in 1961, as the village bank president.

Mrs. Roem Y. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Moreover, she is also a basket maker.

Mrs. Roem Y. faces a problem in that it is time to plow her field but she does not have enough money to do so. So, to improve production, she is asking for a loA. to hire a plowing machine to plow her field. With the rest of the loA., she plans to buy two piglets to raise to start a new business.

Mrs. Roem Y. is a widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is enrolled in school.

loans.use: To hire a plowing machine to plow her field and to buy two piglets to raise

loans.name: Kok

texts.en:
Kok K., 53, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and five children. She makes about $3 daily selling groceries, while her husband makes $1.50 as a construction worker. Beside these businesses, this couple also grows rice to support their family. 

She is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase more groceries to expand her current shop and to buy a water pump to irrigate her farmland. She is also hoping to purchase a pig to raise and sell with the money from the loan. She sees this loan as a great opportunity to expand her business and is confident that she will see her income increase as a result.

loans.use: Expand grocery products and purchase a water pump

loans.name: Chinzorig

texts.en: Chinzorig J. is 26 years old and single. He lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Chinzorig has a small business running a photo service booth. He has been running his photo service booth for the last five years and has gained an abundant amount of experience in professional photography. One of his dreams is to open his own photo studio where customers would have the chance to dress up in Mongolian traditional clothes while having their photos taken. He is requesting a 1,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase Mongolian traditional clothes and some equipment for his business.

loans.use: To purchase Mongolian traditional clothes and some equipment for his business

loans.name: Roselily

Roselily has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP per harvest.

This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Roselily from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Pha So Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has eighteen people who live in Doun Pheu village, Takeo province. Mrs. Pha S., who was born in 1961, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan to support their various businesses.

Mrs. Pha S. is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She faces an obstacle in that it is time to plow her field but she does not have enough money to support doing S.. S., to improve production, she is seeking a loan to hire a plowing machine to plow her field. With the rest of the loan she plans to buy fertilizer.

Mrs. Pha S. is a widow with three children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other is studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To hire a plowing machine to plow her field and to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Uom

texts.en: Uom M. is 28 years old and lives with his wife in the Takeo province. He is a construction worker building houses, typically making US$5 of profit a day, while his wife works outside of the house as a garment factory worker. On average, she makes US$3 per day. This couple has one young child at home that they support. Uom M. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to do farming, growing beans for his family's additional income.

loans.use: To grow beans.

loans.name: Hatanbaatar

texts.en: Hatanbaatar U. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province,  in central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two sons attend a local middle school. Hatanbaatar and his wife operate a clothing retail business in their town. He began his business in 2003. At that time he operated his business in a rented stall at the local market. He has since expanded his business and currently his working capital is approximately 2,680,000 MNT. He plans on opening his own store one day. He says, “My only wish is to be able to afford my children’s education and to help them lead good lives.” Hatanbaatar is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan in order to import more goods from Ereen, a border city of China, to attract new customers.

loans.use: To purchase clothing inventory.

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: Chen S., 34, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. sells beverages and food for an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband provides security services for the motorbikes, earning an income of USD 5 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more beverages and food to expand the current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more beverages and food to expand the business.

Aside from that, she also retails rice grain in her store. Rona Lorraine has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 13500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rona Lorraine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rona Lorraine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rona Lorraine is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Rona Lorraine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn T. is from the town of Banga. She is 37 years old. Analyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Analyn owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Analyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Analyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Analyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be the second loan taken out by Analyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Meth

texts.en:
Meth S., 58, is widowed and resides with her five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. stays at home. Two of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of $8 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Also, her daughter is clothes seller, earning an income of $7 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more clothes for her daughter to expand her business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Boriya

texts.en:
Boriya E. is 56 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Baganuur, an outskirt district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own apartment. His two sons attend an occupational-training center, while his wife helps with his business. 

Boriya owns and operates his own shoe-repair business. He began his business in 1998 and has since gained much working experience, which gives him greater access to more customers. His dream is to grow his business so that he and his family can build their own shop with a set of services. 

Boriya is a modest, honest and responsible person. He is requesting a 600,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to buy more repair supplies and tools for his business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and tools

loans.name: Gereltuya

texts.en:
Gereltuya N. lives with her son and parents in their own apartment in Baganuur, an outskirt district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She operates a consumer goods and clothing retailing business. She began her business in 2005 at a trading stall. 

Gereltuya sells a variety of women's clothing and her products are well-known for their quality and design. She is the kind of person who is hardworking and modest and wants to increase her business revenues. 

Gereltuya is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase more clothing in Beijing, China, at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

L. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

Sakina lives in the historic city of Lahore in Pakistan. She is a housewife as well as a working woman, sewing clothes for her neighborhood clients to earn an income. She is very good at her art and gets regular orders.

Sakina’s husband owns a scrap shop in the market where he buys and sells used wooden and iron items at cheap prices. He has been doing this work for over seven years. He makes a 2% margin on each item which enables him to earn a good income.

Sakina has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy more scrap material to sell in his shop. Sakina hopes that her husband’s business will improve and it will help him to earn a good income as well.

loans.use: To purchase more scrap for her husband's scrap shop
